\section{Structure du dossier \sphinxstylestrong{docs}}
\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut01:structure-du-dossier-docs}}
Il s'agit du dossier contenant les fichiers source au format \sphinxcode{.rst} permettant soit de produire une \sphinxstyleemphasis{sortie} \sphinxcode{.html}, soit une sortie{}`{}`.pdf{}`{}`.

Un fois placé dans le répertoire \sphinxcode{docs} la commande suivante \sphinxcode{tree /f} donne le résultat suivant (la commande \sphinxcode{tree} seule n'aurait indiqué que les répertoires):

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{À faire}

à corriger
\end{sphinxadmonition}

Odoo celebrates freedom. Freedom for the designer to go further and
freedom for the user to customize everything according to their needs \DUrole{xref,std,std-term}{Manifold}.

Ready to create your own theme? Great. Here are some things you should know before you begin. This tutorial is a guide to creating an Odoo theme.

\section{An introduction for web designers}
\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut01:an-introduction-for-web-designers}}
If you are a web designer using Odoo for the first time, you are in the right place.
This introduction will outline the basics of Odoo theme creation.

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
Odoo’s team has created a framework that’s powerful and easy to use. There’s no need to know special syntaxes to use this set of tools.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\subsection{Minimizing images}
\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut01:minimizing-images}}
Optimize image compression where possible. For PNG files, use OptiPNG and AdvanceCOMP’s advpng:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZdl{} \PYG{n+nb}{cd} docs/
\PYGZdl{} optipng \PYGZhy{}o7 \PYGZhy{}zm1\PYGZhy{}9 \PYGZhy{}i0 \PYGZhy{}strip all \PYG{l+s+sb}{{}`}find . \PYGZhy{}type f \PYGZhy{}not \PYGZhy{}path \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}./\PYGZus{}build/*\PYGZdq{}} \PYGZhy{}name \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}*.png\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+sb}{{}`}
\PYGZdl{} advpng \PYGZhy{}z4 \PYG{l+s+sb}{{}`}find . \PYGZhy{}type f \PYGZhy{}not \PYGZhy{}path \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}./\PYGZus{}build/*\PYGZdq{}} \PYGZhy{}name \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}*.png\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+sb}{{}`}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

This is based on OptiPNG version 0.7.5. Older versions may complain about the --strip all option being lossy.

\subsection{Workflow}
\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut01:workflow}}

\subsubsection{Transform Driver}
\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut01:transform-driver}}
This example shows you how setup a transform driver.
First make sure you are in the Front Ortho view. \sphinxcode{Numpad5}, \sphinxcode{Numpad1}.
\begin{enumerate}
\item {} 
In object mode, select then duplicate the default Cube. \sphinxcode{Shift-D}. Move ``Cube.001'' to a new location.

\item {} 
With ``Cube.001'' selected, add a single driver to the \sphinxstyleemphasis{Rotation Y} property.

\item {} 
Open the \sphinxstyleemphasis{Graph Editor}, set the Mode to \sphinxstyleemphasis{Drivers}.

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleemphasis{Show Only Selected} is useful disabled for drivers, marked green in the picture.

\item {} 
In the channels region, select the \sphinxstyleemphasis{Y Euler Rotation} property.

\item {} 
Press \sphinxcode{N} to open the properties region, scroll down to Drivers panel.

\item {} 
Change the \sphinxstyleemphasis{Type} to \sphinxstyleemphasis{Averaged Value}, this will return the averaged value of the driver variables.

\item {} 
Modify the driver variable settings:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Type -- Transform Channel

\item {} 
Ob/Bone -- Cube

\item {} 
Transform Type -- X Location

\item {} 
Transform Space -- World Space

\end{itemize}

\end{enumerate}
\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\capstart

\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics[width=600\sphinxpxdimen]{{9b7452_4929c05fd6e54bf4a3099691f68ab423}.jpg}
\caption{Animation}\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut01:id8}}\end{figure}

When finished, ``Cube.001'' should rotate on the Y axis when moving ``Cube'' left to right.


\subsubsection{Drivers And Multiple Relative Shape Keys}
\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut01:drivers-and-multiple-relative-shape-keys}}
The following screenshots illustrate combining shape keys, bones, and
drivers to make multiple chained relative shape keys sharing a single
root. While it lacks the convenience of the single Evaluation Time of
an absolute shape key, it allows you to have more complex
relationships between your shape keys.


\begin{threeparttable}
\capstart\caption{euh y'en pa 1 pe bocou la ?}\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut01:id9}}
\noindent\begin{tabulary}{\linewidth}{|L|L|}
\hline
\begin{sphinxfigure-in-table}
\centering
\capstart
\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics{{animation_driver_workflow_for-multiple-shape-keys-key1}.png}
\sphinxfigcaption{Key1 must handle conflicting values from the two bones.}\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut01:id10}}\end{sphinxfigure-in-table}\relax
&\begin{sphinxfigure-in-table}
\centering
\capstart
\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics{{animation_driver_workflow_for-multiple-shape-keys-key2a}.png}
\sphinxfigcaption{Key2A has different generator coefficients so it is activated in a different range of the bone's position.}\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut01:id11}}\end{sphinxfigure-in-table}\relax
\\
\hline\begin{sphinxfigure-in-table}
\centering
\capstart
\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics{{animation_driver_workflow_for-multiple-shape-keys-key2b}.png}
\sphinxfigcaption{Key2B is the same as Key2A, but is controlled by the second bone.}\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut01:id12}}\end{sphinxfigure-in-table}\relax
&\begin{sphinxfigure-in-table}
\centering
\capstart
\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics{{animation_driver_workflow_for-multiple-shape-keys-retracted}.png}
\sphinxfigcaption{When both bones are low, Key2B and Key2A are deactivated and Key1 is at low influence.}\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut01:id13}}\end{sphinxfigure-in-table}\relax
\\
\hline\begin{sphinxfigure-in-table}
\centering
\capstart
\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics{{animation_driver_workflow_for-multiple-shape-keys-extended}.png}
\sphinxfigcaption{et quoi dire de plus?}\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut01:id14}}\end{sphinxfigure-in-table}\relax
&\\
\hline\end{tabulary}

\end{threeparttable}


The Basis shape key has the stacks fully retracted. Key1 has the base fully extended.
Key2A has the left stack fully extended. Key2B has the right stack fully extended.
Key2A and Key2B are both relative to Key1 (as you can see in the field
in the bottom right of the Shape Keys panel.

The value of Key1 is bound to the position of bones by a driver with
two variables. Each variable uses the world Z coordinate of a bone
and uses the maximum value to determine how much the base should be
extended. The generator polynomial is crafted such that the top of
the dominant stack should line up with the bone for that stack.

The value of Key2A is bound to the position of ``Bone.L''.
Its generator parameters are crafted such that when Key1's value reaches 1,
the value of Key2A starts increasing beyond zero. In this way,
the top of the left stack will move with bone.L (mostly).

The value of Key2B is bound to the position of ``Bone.R''. Its generator
parameters are similar to Key2A so that the top of the right stack
will move with bone.R (mostly).

Since it is quite easy for bone.L and bone.R to be in positions that
indicate conflicting values for Key1 there will be times when the
bones do not line up with the tops of their respective stacks. If the
driver for Key1 was to use Average or Minimum instead of Maximum to
determine the value of the shape key then ``conflicts'' between bone.L
and bone.R would be resolved differently. You will choose according to
the needs of your animation.


\subsubsection{From common CMS to Odoo}
\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut01:from-common-cms-to-odoo}}
\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
If you always think and work in the same way, you’ll probably get the same results. If you want something completely new,  then try something different.
\end{sphinxadmonition}


\subsection{Composition of a module}
\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut01:composition-of-a-module}}\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut01:autocad-tut01-mod-jan20}}
An Odoo module can contain a number of elements:
\begin{description}
\item[{Business objects}] \leavevmode
declared as Python classes, these resources are automatically persisted
by Odoo based on their configuration

\item[{Data files}] \leavevmode
XML or CSV files declaring metadata (views or workflows), configuration
data (modules parameterization), demonstration data and more

\item[{Web controllers}] \leavevmode
Handle requests from web browsers

\item[{Static web data}] \leavevmode
Images, CSS or javascript files used by the web interface or website

\end{description}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Reference}

\begin{DUlineblock}{0em}
\item[] Mode:     Object Mode
\item[] Hotkey:   \sphinxcode{Ctrl-Numpad0}
\end{DUlineblock}
\end{sphinxadmonition}


\section{Render Border}
\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut01:render-border}}
\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Reference}

\begin{DUlineblock}{0em}
\item[] Mode:     All modes
\item[] Menu:     \sphinxmenuselection{View \(\rightarrow\) Render Border}
\item[] Hotkey:   \sphinxcode{Ctrl-B}
\end{DUlineblock}
\end{sphinxadmonition}
\begin{wrapfigure}{r}{500\sphinxpxdimen}
\centering
\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics[width=500\sphinxpxdimen]{{60897883c74ddba9f88350b924cf7b5d}.jpg}
\end{wrapfigure}

Render Border toggle.

While in camera view, you can define a subregion to render by drawing out a rectangle within the camera's frame.
Your renders will now be limited to the part of scene visible within the render border.
This can be very useful for reducing render times for quick previews on an area of interest.

The border can be disabled by disabling the \sphinxstyleemphasis{Border} option in the \sphinxstyleemphasis{Dimensions} panel
in the \sphinxstyleemphasis{Render} tab or by activating the option again.

Exercitation duis tempor proident tempor commodo Lorem commodo anim laborum cupidatat pariatur dolore esse labore aliquip. Nisi occaecat aliquip dolor excepteur officia id exercitation magna consectetur irure aliqua dolore cillum commodo aliquip. Non dolor est sunt consectetur cillum enim sint.

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
When Render Border is activated, \DUrole{xref,doc}{Motion Blur}
will become available to view in the 3D View.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\subsection{Undo}
\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut01:undo}}
\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Reference}

\begin{DUlineblock}{0em}
\item[] Mode:     All Modes
\item[] Panel:    \sphinxmenuselection{Tool Shelf \(\rightarrow\) Tools \(\rightarrow\) History \(\rightarrow\) Undo}
\item[] Menu:     \sphinxmenuselection{Object/Object types \(\rightarrow\) Undo}
\item[] Hotkey:   \sphinxcode{Ctrl-Z}
\end{DUlineblock}
\end{sphinxadmonition}

If you want to undo your last action, just press \sphinxcode{Ctrl-Z}.


\sphinxstrong{Voir aussi:}


this section on undo to change defaults.




\subsection{Redo}
\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut01:bpy-ops-ed-redo}}\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut01:redo}}
\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Reference}

\begin{DUlineblock}{0em}
\item[] Mode:     All Modes
\item[] Panel:    \sphinxmenuselection{Tool Shelf \(\rightarrow\) Tools \(\rightarrow\) History \(\rightarrow\) Redo}
\item[] Menu:     \sphinxmenuselection{Object/Object types \(\rightarrow\) Redo}
\item[] Hotkey:   \sphinxcode{Ctrl-Shift-Z}
\end{DUlineblock}
\end{sphinxadmonition}

To roll back the Undo action, press \sphinxcode{Ctrl-Shift-Z}.


\subsection{Undo History}
\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut01:undo-history}}
\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Reference}

\begin{DUlineblock}{0em}
\item[] Mode:     All Modes
\item[] Panel:    \sphinxmenuselection{Tool Shelf \(\rightarrow\) Tools \(\rightarrow\) History \(\rightarrow\) Undo History}
\item[] Menu:     \sphinxmenuselection{Object/Object types \(\rightarrow\) Undo History}
\item[] Hotkey:   \sphinxcode{Ctrl-Alt-Z}
\end{DUlineblock}
\end{sphinxadmonition}
\begin{wrapfigure}{r}{500\sphinxpxdimen}
\centering
\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics[width=500\sphinxpxdimen]{{ot6hgwgvkdg7os01}.jpg}
\caption{The Undo History Menu.}\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut01:id18}}\end{wrapfigure}

There is also an Undo History of the last actions taken, recorded by Blender.
You can access the history pop-up with \sphinxcode{Ctrl-Alt-Z}.

First positions correspond to most recent actions.
A small icon of an eye next to one of the entries indicates the current status.
Rolling back actions using the \sphinxstyleemphasis{Undo History} feature will take you back to the
action you choose. Much like how you can alternate between going backward in
time with \sphinxstyleemphasis{Undo} and then forward with \sphinxstyleemphasis{Redo},
you can hop around on the Undo timeline as much as you want as long as you do not make a new change.
Once you do make a new change, the Undo History is truncated at that point.
Selecting one of the entries in the list takes the current status to that position.

\subsection{Repeat Last}
\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut01:repeat-last}}
\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Reference}

\begin{DUlineblock}{0em}
\item[] Mode:     All Modes
\item[] Panel:    \sphinxmenuselection{Tool Shelf \(\rightarrow\) Tools \(\rightarrow\) History \(\rightarrow\) Repeat: Repeat Last}
\item[] Hotkey:   \sphinxcode{Shift-R}
\end{DUlineblock}
\end{sphinxadmonition}

The Repeat Last feature will repeat your last action when you press \sphinxcode{Shift-R}.

In the example Images below, we duplicated a \sphinxstyleemphasis{Monkey} mesh,
and then we moved the Object a bit.
Using repeat \sphinxcode{Shift-R}, the \sphinxstyleemphasis{Monkey} was also duplicated and moved.

\subsection{Repeat History}
\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut01:repeat-history}}\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut01:bpy-ops-ed-undo-history}}
\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Reference}

\begin{DUlineblock}{0em}
\item[] Mode:     All Modes
\item[] Panel:    \sphinxmenuselection{Tool Shelf \(\rightarrow\) Tools \(\rightarrow\) History \(\rightarrow\) Repeat: History...}
\item[] Hotkey:   \sphinxcode{F3}
\end{DUlineblock}
\end{sphinxadmonition}
\begin{wrapfigure}{r}{0pt}
\centering
\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics[height=200\sphinxpxdimen]{{tumblr_mfe80vYmn31qat99uo4_500}.jpg}
\end{wrapfigure}

The Repeat History Menu.

The \sphinxstyleemphasis{Repeat History} feature will present you a list of the last repeated actions,
and you can choose the actions you want to repeat.
It works in the same way as the Undo History, explained above,
but the list contains only repeated actions. To access Repeat History, use \sphinxcode{F3}.

\section{Configuring PDF rendering}
\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut01:configuring-pdf-rendering}}
If you want docs.typo3.org to generate a PDF file out of your documentation project, your
documentation project must have a file \sphinxcode{Settings.yml} (located at the root of your
\sphinxcode{Documentation/} folder). Make sure this file, inside a block for \sphinxcode{conf.py},
at least contains the following configuration options (lines 6 to 15);
in this example taken from the TYPO3 extension ``sphinx'':

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\},numbers=left,firstnumber=1,stepnumber=1]
\PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{conf.py}\PYG{p+pIndicator}{:}
\PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{copyright}\PYG{p+pIndicator}{:} \PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{2013\PYGZhy{}2014}
\PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{project}\PYG{p+pIndicator}{:} \PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{Sphinx}\PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{ }\PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{Python}\PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{ }\PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{Documentation}\PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{ }\PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{Generator}\PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{ }\PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{and}\PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{ }\PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{Viewer}
\PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{version}\PYG{p+pIndicator}{:} \PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{2.1}
\PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{release}\PYG{p+pIndicator}{:} \PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{2.1.0}
\PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{latex\PYGZus{}documents}\PYG{p+pIndicator}{:}
\PYG{p+pIndicator}{\PYGZhy{}} \PYG{p+pIndicator}{\PYGZhy{}} \PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{Index}
   \PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{ }\PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{sphinx.tex}
   \PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{ }\PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{Sphinx}\PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{ }\PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{Python}\PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{ }\PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{Documentation}\PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{ }\PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{Generator}\PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{ }\PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{and}\PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{ }\PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{Viewer}
   \PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{ }\PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{Xavier}\PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{ }\PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{Perseguers}
   \PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{ }\PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{manual}
\PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{latex\PYGZus{}elements}\PYG{p+pIndicator}{:}
\PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{papersize}\PYG{p+pIndicator}{:} \PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{a4paper}
\PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{pointsize}\PYG{p+pIndicator}{:} \PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{10pt}
\PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{preamble}\PYG{p+pIndicator}{:} \PYG{l+lScalar+lScalarPlain}{\PYGZbs{}usepackage\PYGZob{}typo3\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

Lines 7 to 11 define options for value \sphinxcode{latex\_documents} which determines how to group the document tree into LaTeX
source files. This is a list of tuples: \sphinxcode{startdocname}, \sphinxcode{targetname}, \sphinxcode{title}, \sphinxcode{author}, \sphinxcode{documentclass}, where
the items are:
\begin{description}
\item[{startdocname}] \leavevmode
Document name that is the ``root'' of the LaTeX files. All documents referenced by it in TOC trees will be included
in the LaTeX file too.

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{warning}{Avertissement:}
Always use \sphinxcode{Index} here.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\item[{targetname}] \leavevmode
File name of the LaTeX file in the output directory.

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{warning}{Avertissement:}
Always use your extension key followed by \sphinxcode{.tex} here.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\item[{title}] \leavevmode
LaTeX document title. This is inserted as LaTeX markup, so special characters like a backslash or ampersand must be
represented by the proper LaTeX commands if they are to be inserted literally.

\item[{author}] \leavevmode
Author for the LaTeX document. The same LaTeX markup caveat as for \sphinxstyleemphasis{title} applies. Use \sphinxcode{\textbackslash{}and} to separate
multiple authors, as in: \sphinxcode{'John \textbackslash{}and Sarah'}.

\item[{documentclass}] \leavevmode
Normally, one of \sphinxcode{manual} or \sphinxcode{howto} (provided by Sphinx).

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{tip}{Astuce:}
To keep TYPO3 branding, you should always use \sphinxcode{manual} here.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\end{description}

Lines 12 to 15 should be kept as they are. Especially the exact content of line 15 is important:
This code actually is the ``trigger'' for PDF rendering.

When activated, your PDF automatically gets rendered on \url{https://docs.typo3.org} under
\sphinxcode{https://docs.typo3.org/typo3cms/extensions/\sphinxstyleemphasis{extension-key}/\_pdf/}. E.g.,
\url{https://docs.typo3.org/typo3cms/extensions/sphinx/\_pdf/}.

(Information taken from the \href{https://docs.typo3.org/typo3cms/extensions/sphinx/WritersManual/DocsTypo3Org/Index.html\#pdf-rendering}{documentation of the sphinx extension}%
\begin{footnote}[4]\sphinxAtStartFootnote
\nolinkurl{https://docs.typo3.org/typo3cms/extensions/sphinx/WritersManual/DocsTypo3Org/Index.html\#pdf-rendering}
%
\end{footnote} by Xavier Perseguers.)

\subsection{Récupérer des fichiers supprimés en local}
\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut01:recuperer-des-fichiers-supprimes-en-local}}

\subsubsection{Avant}
\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut01:avant}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
On est dans le repo \sphinxcode{edx-sphinx-theme}, à récupérer avec git par la commande suivante:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZdl{} git clone https://github.com/edx/edx\PYGZhy{}sphinx\PYGZhy{}theme.git
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\item {} 
on a modifié des fichiers ... et sutout, supprimé quelque uns ...

\end{itemize}


\subsubsection{Pendant}
\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut01:pendant}}
On cherche donc à retourner à l'état original du répertoire local.

Il n'y a plus qu'à exécuter cette commande pour connaitre les fichiers supprimés en local:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZdl{} git ls\PYGZhy{}files \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}deleted
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

retourne:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\},numbers=left,firstnumber=1,stepnumber=1]
edx\PYGZus{}theme/static/font/fontawesome\PYGZus{}webfont.eot
edx\PYGZus{}theme/static/font/fontawesome\PYGZus{}webfont.svg
edx\PYGZus{}theme/static/font/fontawesome\PYGZus{}webfont.ttf
edx\PYGZus{}theme/static/font/fontawesome\PYGZus{}webfont.woff
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

En exécutant la commande suivante:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZdl{} git checkout \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{} edx\PYGZus{}theme/static/font/*
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

On récupère d'un coup toutes les polices que l'on avait accidentellement supprimé.


\subsection{Télécharger \sphinxstylestrong{un seul} fichier depuis un dépôt distant Github}
\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut01:telecharger-un-seul-fichier-depuis-un-depot-distant-github}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Open the file in the browser

\item {} 
click on ``Raw'' button

\item {} 
Now refresh your browser, copy the url

\item {} 
and do a wget or curl on it.

\end{itemize}

wget example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
wget https://github.abc.abc.com/raw/abc/folder1/master/folder2/myfile.py?token=DDDDnkl92Kw8829jhXXoxBaVJIYW\PYGZhy{}h7zks5Vy9I\PYGZhy{}wA\PYGZpc{}3D\PYGZpc{}3D \PYGZhy{}O myfile.py

wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/TYPO3\PYGZhy{}Documentation/TYPO3CMS\PYGZhy{}Book\PYGZhy{}ExtbaseFluid/Documentation/Targets.rst
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

Curl example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{curl} \PYG{n}{https}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{example}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{com}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{raw}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{txt} \PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{n}{savedFile}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{txt}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

are specified

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{tip}{Astuce:}
most command-line options can also be set using
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\subsubsection{Start lessons}
\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut01:start-lessons}}\begin{enumerate}
\item {} 
To open a lesson, go to \sphinxmenuselection{Plugins \(\rightarrow\) Lessons \(\rightarrow\) Start Lesson}. The \sphinxmenuselection{Lesson selector} will show up.
\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering

\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics{{objects}.png}
\end{figure}

\item {} 
If Boundless Connect plugin was configured to use a local directory-based repository instead of the remote one, then you don't need to enter any credentials, and you can go directly to \sphinxmenuselection{Plugins \(\rightarrow\) Manage and install plugins}.

\item {} 
The lessons are organized in groups. If necessary, click the cross next to the group's name to expand its lessons list.

\item {} 
The following buttons compose the button bar:

\end{enumerate}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Move to next step} - To go to the next lesson's step.

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Run step} - Helps performing the steps instructions (not always available).

\item {} 
\sphinxstylestrong{Restart lesson} - Resets the project and cleans all the lesson's progress made so far.

\end{itemize}

Even few steps below, a reference to {\hyperref[\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut01:my-figure}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Belle figure 01 caption}}}} (\autopageref*{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut01:my-figure}}) would insert a reference to the figure with link text “Belle figure 01 caption”.


\subsubsection{Remotes}
\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut01:remotes}}
Remotes are ``remote repositories'' which can be fetched from and pushed
to. Remotes can be listed with \sphinxcode{git remote} and a local
repository can have any number of remotes. The setup script creates 2 remotes:
\begin{description}
\item[{\sphinxcode{odoo}}] \leavevmode
the official repository and main branches, roughly corresponds to the old
``mainline'' branches in bazaar. You should never need to push to it, and by
default your local copy is configured to forbid it.

\item[{\sphinxcode{odoo-dev}}] \leavevmode
a grab-bag of development branches, you can push your work to it so other
coworkers can work with you.

\end{description}


\subsubsection{Branches}
\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut01:branches}}
The working copy and each remote contain multiple branches. Local branches can
be listed by \sphinxcode{git branch}, remote branches can be listed with \sphinxcode{git branch
-r}. Both types can be listed with \sphinxcode{git branch -a}.

Work is only possible on local branches, even though it's possible to check
out a remote branch work on it will be lost.


\subsubsection{Staging}
\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut01:staging}}
\sphinxcode{bzr commit} takes all alterations to the working copy and creates a commit
from them. Git has an intermediate step called ``staging''. \sphinxcode{git commit} will
create a commit from what has been staged, not from the working copy. Staging is done with \sphinxcode{git add}. A commit with nothing
staged is a null operation.

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{warning}{Avertissement:}
It's possible for a single file to have changes in both the index and
working copy: if a file is altered, staged and altered again, the second
set of change has to be staged separately
\end{sphinxadmonition}


\subsubsection{SHA1}
\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut01:sha1}}
Git has no sequential identifier, each commit is uniquely identified by a SHA
(40 hexadecimal characters) roughly corresponding to a bazaar
revision-id. Providing the full sha is rarely necessary, any unique leading
substring is sufficient, e.g. \sphinxcode{dae86e} will probably stand in for
\sphinxcode{dae86e1950b1277e545cee180551750029cfe735}.


\subsection{Basic development workflow}
\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut01:basic-development-workflow}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
update your remotes with \sphinxcode{git fetch -{-}all}

\item {} 
create your development branch with \sphinxcode{git checkout -b \textless{}branch\_name\textgreater{}
\textless{}source\_branch\textgreater{}}. For instance if you wanted to add support for full-text
search in master you could use \sphinxcode{git checkout -b master-fts-xxx odoo/master}

\item {} 
do your changes, stage them with \sphinxcode{git add} and commit them with \sphinxcode{git
commit}

\item {} 
if your branch is long-lived, you may want to update it to its parent
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
update the remotes with \sphinxcode{git fetch -{-}all}

\item {} 
merge the remote branch into the local one with \sphinxcode{git merge -{-}no-ff
odoo/master}

\end{itemize}

\item {} 
to push the branch to the development repository, use \sphinxcode{git push -u dev
\textless{}branchname\textgreater{}}, this will automatically create a branch called
\sphinxcode{\textless{}branchname\textgreater{}} on dev. Next time around you do not have to use \sphinxcode{-u}

\item {} 
once the feature is done, create a pull request

\end{itemize}


\subsection{Minimizing images}
\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut01:id2}}
Optimize image compression where possible. For PNG files, use OptiPNG and AdvanceCOMP’s advpng:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZdl{} cd docs/
\PYGZdl{} optipng \PYGZhy{}o7 \PYGZhy{}zm1\PYGZhy{}9 \PYGZhy{}i0 \PYGZhy{}strip all {}`find . \PYGZhy{}type f \PYGZhy{}not \PYGZhy{}path \PYGZdq{}./\PYGZus{}build/*\PYGZdq{} \PYGZhy{}name \PYGZdq{}*.png\PYGZdq{}{}`
\PYGZdl{} advpng \PYGZhy{}z4 {}`find . \PYGZhy{}type f \PYGZhy{}not \PYGZhy{}path \PYGZdq{}./\PYGZus{}build/*\PYGZdq{} \PYGZhy{}name \PYGZdq{}*.png\PYGZdq{}{}`
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{Using GitHub pages}
\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut01:using-github-pages}}
This is the option I will describe in some detail, since it may be a
little involved and also I haven't tried this yet, myself.

First, create a new \sphinxstyleemphasis{empty} repository with no README on \href{http://www.github.com}{GitHub}%
\begin{footnote}[5]\sphinxAtStartFootnote
\nolinkurl{http://www.github.com}
%
\end{footnote}. Let's call it \sphinxtitleref{site}. Now, clone the
repository:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{git} \PYG{n}{clone} \PYG{n}{https}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{github}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{com}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{amitsaha}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{site}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{git}
        \PYG{n}{Cloning} \PYG{n}{into} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{site}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{o}{.}
        \PYG{n}{warning}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{You} \PYG{n}{appear} \PYG{n}{to} \PYG{n}{have} \PYG{n}{cloned} \PYG{n}{an} \PYG{n}{empty} \PYG{n}{repository}\PYG{o}{.}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

Create a \sphinxcode{gh-pages} branch in your repository and switch to it:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{git} \PYG{n}{checkout} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{b} \PYG{n}{gh}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{pages}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

Now, copy \sphinxstyleemphasis{all} the files and directories in \sphinxcode{html} directory to this
directory:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{git} \PYG{n}{add} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{a}
\PYG{n}{git} \PYG{n}{commit} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{m} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{first commit of static HTML}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

Now, push the \sphinxcode{gh-pages} branch to the remote repository:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{git} \PYG{n}{push} \PYG{n}{origin} \PYG{n}{gh}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{pages}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

Once that is complete, you can now go to the URL:
\sphinxcode{http://github-user-name.github.com/site} to see your pages. See
\href{http://amitsaha.github.com/site/demo}{this}%
\begin{footnote}[6]\sphinxAtStartFootnote
\nolinkurl{http://amitsaha.github.com/site/demo}
%
\end{footnote} page as an example.

You can of course now have multiple directories in the \sphinxcode{site}
repository and then you can host a different set of static pages.

For example, ``demo'' dir

Now, let us say that you want to store your HTML files in a separate
directory, called \sphinxcode{demo}:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{mkdir} \PYG{n}{demo}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

Now, copy \sphinxstyleemphasis{all} the files and directories in \sphinxcode{html} directory to this
directory.

Add the \sphinxcode{demo} directory to Git and commit the changes:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{git} \PYG{n}{add} \PYG{n}{demo}
\PYG{n}{git} \PYG{n}{commit} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{m} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Created }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{n}{demo}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{ dir and first commit of static HTML in demo}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

Now, push the \sphinxcode{gh-pages} branch to the remote repository:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{git} \PYG{n}{push} \PYG{n}{origin} \PYG{n}{gh}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{pages}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut02::doc}}\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut02:autodesk}}\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut02:autocad-tut02}}\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut02:autocad-tutoriel-02}}

\item {}

\item {} 
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut02:id2}}{\hyperref[\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut02:from-common-cms-to-odoo}]{\sphinxcrossref{From common CMS to Odoo}}} (\autopageref*{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut02:from-common-cms-to-odoo}})

\item {} 
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut02:id3}}{\hyperref[\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut02:flutuat-nec-mergitur-1}]{\sphinxcrossref{Flutuat nec mergitur 1}}} (\autopageref*{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut02:flutuat-nec-mergitur-1}})

\end{itemize}
\end{sphinxShadowBox}

Odoo celebrates freedom. Freedom for the designer to go further and
freedom for the user to customize everything according to their needs.

Ready to create your own theme? Great. Here are some things you should know before you begin. This tutorial is a guide to creating an Odoo theme.

\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics{{color_scatter}.png}


\section{An introduction for web designers}
\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut02:an-introduction-for-web-designers}}
If you are a web designer using Odoo for the first time, you are in the right place.
This introduction will outline the basics of Odoo theme creation.

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
Odoo’s team has created a framework that’s powerful and easy to use. There’s no need to know special syntaxes to use this set of tools.
\end{sphinxadmonition}


\section{From common CMS to Odoo}
\label{\detokenize{docs/tuts/autocad-tut02:from-common-cms-to-odoo}}
\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
If you always think and work in the same way, you’ll probably get the same results. If you want something completely new,  then try something different.
\end{sphinxadmonition}
